subtitle: 18 months. Zero precedent. One solo designer.

contentBlocks.quote: When Standard Tools Don’t Exist, You Build Your Own.
contentBlocks.context: Building a design system in JavaFX felt like being handed a puzzle with no picture on the box. No existing examples, no standard tools, no safety net. Just me, a proof-of-concept deadline, and a CEO who’d already said no once.

blocks.text: From the moment I walked in I realised I was in an engineer-first environment. Design was seen as “nice to have” rather than essential. Developers didn’t understand what value a design system could bring to them.

Senapt is a UK-based startup building energy software (B2B). The company had already built one successful white-label product. This marketing management platform was to be the second one, and proof of concept for a larger future Suite. Design culture was still growing when I joined in February 2024

items: Zero systematisation — no libraries, no variables, no styles, no naming conventions in any of the products
Legacy projects scattered across Sketch and other tools with no documentation
Prior designer's work with zero handoff notes
No UX research, minimal wireframing, almost no prototyping
No single source of truth for brand or UI decisions
100% static Figma designs with basic annotations
4-5 QA rounds per feature as standard
Developers sometimes bypassed design and pushed directly to production
Limited "respect" for design as a discipline

The Context: No Design Systems precedent in the company
Occasional push to prod without QA
The Project's Team:
Frontend Dev
+8h timezone different, limited English, written communication only

blocks.text:
In 16 months, I built a design system from absolute zero.
The CEO who initially rejected my design system pitch eventually asked me to implement it company-wide. This is the story of how I proved its value by building it anyway.

items.label: saved through component reuse across the team
Automated handoffs with a custom Figma-to-Git pipeline
onboarded to system spanning multiple tech stacks after CEO validation

columns.heading: The Constraints that made it nearly impossible

blocks.text:
After much research I found no existing design system examples or precedent.
None of the standard DS tools (Supernova, Storybook, Zeroheight) gave support for JavaFX.
It also required specific output that differs from standard web CSS and there were no documented token naming conventions, structures or component libraries

My Frontend dev was not only +8hours ahead of me, but there was also a language barrier only allowing for written English communication (no video calls).
As many developers, his familiarity with Figma was limited.
We worked side by side to elaborate the most asynchronous yet precise system possible; meaning I could overstep into "code territory" and handle the variables transformations and delivery myself.

This was one of those rare oportunities were you get to built something from scratch. I had no existing product to audit, no legacy brand or components; but I also had NO prior experience building a whole design system from the ground up.
This could have been my full-time job, but with no product manager, no UX and no resources allocated I ended up building the product and simultaneosly building the system.

contentBlocks.title:
CEO:
"Products are working. Nobody's complained. This isn't a priority."
contentBlocks.insight: Before being assigned this project, I observed the chaos and pitched design systems to the CEO and stakeholders. VP of Frontend saw potential selfish value for developers; but proposal was denied.
contentBlocks.result: I chose to build it anyway — without formal approval, without dedicated resources, on top of my UI/UX/Product responsibilities.

content.text: I drafted a priority roadmap in three stages, attempting to balance theory with the reality of FE waiting for deliverables:
Stage 1 (Core Foundations):

items: Colour ramps for brand and neutrals

content.text: Stage 2 (Semantic Layer):

items: Define semantics for backgrounds, text, icons, strokes

content.text: Stage 3 (Advanced Components):
Reality: This roadmap lasted approximately 2 weeks before the actual needs of shipping a product took over.
What Happened:

items: Researched visual direction and proof-of-concept screens
Front-end brought into the project in the same meeting where designs were approved
FE asked to start working immediately

content.text: State of Design at This Stage:

items: Library contained only colours and text family

content.text: The Problem: I was trying to set design system foundations with only a rough idea of look and feel. No component library. No system to build on. Just custom-made everything while FE was already waiting for deliverables.
Design Decisions Made Under Pressure:
FE Constraints Immediately Added:
This is where my inexperience became very apparent. I made classic novice mistakes:
Mistake #1: Jumping to Component Tokens Too Early
I created component-level tokens (for buttons, inputs, cards) that pointed directly to core tokens, skipping the semantic layer entirely.

Why this was wrong: No logical hierarchy. When I needed to change a button's hover state, I had to edit the component token directly rather than updating a semantic "interactive-hover" token that could apply everywhere.
Mistake #2: Approaching Semantics from Theory, Not Reality
When I finally built the semantic layer, I based it on what I'd read about design systems, not on what I'd actually built in the UI.
The result:

items: Chaotic categories (surfaces AND backgrounds as separate concepts?)
Semantics included gradients at the wrong level
No clear hierarchy between semantic categories

content.text: Mistake #3: Too Many Transparencies
I initially created dozens of alpha values for transparency (70%, 50%, 30%, 15%, 5%) without auditing if solid equivalents existed. This created inconsistency and confusion.
The fix: Standardised to fewer alpha values and searched for solid colour equivalents wherever possible.
I had to rebuild the semantic layer from scratch.
New Approach:

items: Audited what actually existed in the UI rather than theorising

Defined key semantic categories: Surface (backgrounds for cards, containers), Stroke (borders, dividers), Content (text, icons), Spacing (margin, padding, gaps), Overlays (modals, tooltips, scrims), Effects (shadows, blurs), Feedback (error, success, warning, info states)

Created "Flavours + Levels" naming system: Flavours: Neutral, Brand | Levels: 2XS, XS, S, M, L, XL, 2XL (for sizing) | Intensity: extrabold, bold, contrast, main, light, subtle, extrasubtle, inverted, hidden (for colour)
All component tokens now pointed to semantics, creating proper hierarchy

content.text: While reworking tokens, I still had to deliver features to FE. The async timezone gap (+8 hours) and language barrier made this brutal.
Initial Handoff Flow:

items: Export CSS values via Figma plugin
Manually rearrange tokens in correct order (core, semantics, components)
Send ZIP file of CSS to FE

content.text: Problems:

items: FE received plain CSS, but needed JavaFX-specific CSS

content.text: First Attempt: Token Studio JSON
I tried using Token Studio to push JSON files directly to Git.
FE Response: "Why JSON? That's not a useful file format for us."
Denied.
Second Attempt: Direct Git Access
VP of FE gave me access to the company repo. I pushed CSS files directly from my machine.
Better, but still: Manual copy-paste from Figma, manual cleaning, manual rearranging. FE still had issues with CSS transformations not being JavaFX-ready.

phases.title: Months 10-12: The Git Automation Hero Moment

content.text: The Breaking Point:
I was spending 2-3 hours per handoff just wrangling CSS files. FE was grateful, but I knew there had to be a better way. The pain points were:

items: Token order didn't match Figma structure
No way to see what changed between versions

content.text: The Research Phase:
I reached out to the company's Fullstack developer (not on my project) and asked for help scoping a solution. Together, we identified GitHub Actions as the answer.
What I Needed to Learn (With Almost Zero Prior Git Knowledge):

items: How to trigger actions from Token Studio pushes
How to transform JSON to CSS programmatically
How to create multiple output files
How to add metadata and documentation to generated files

content.text: The Build:
Fullstack dev helped me set up the initial workflow. From that point, I iterated and polished it through trial, error, and long conversations with AI chatbots.

items: Version 1: Basic transformation - Token Studio JSON pushed to Git, GitAction triggered, Output: Standard CSS file, Tokens ordered same as Figma Variables
Version 2: Nested variables - Added variable nesting for better organisation
Version 3: Alphabetical ordering - Tokens alphabetically sorted within their Collections, Collections ordered same as in Figma
Version 4: Documentation layer - Timestamps added to file header, Token count metadata, Number of collections and modes tracked, File becomes self-documenting
Version 5: Figma comments - Comments from Figma Variables appear as inline CSS comments
Version 6: Dual output - Standard CSS (:root), JavaFX-specific CSS (.root + grammar adjustments)
Version 7: Gradient handling - Separate GitAction for gradients (different syntax in JavaFX)

content.text: The Result
Handoff time: 3 seconds.
Whenever I accumulated enough token changes, I pushed to Git. GitAction ran automatically. Both CSS files updated and were ready for FE to consume.
The impact on FE:

items: No more chasing me for handoffs

content.text: The impact on me:

items: Proved value through developer pain point solved, not just designer convenience

blocks.text: During a design team meeting, the CEO showed particular interest in this project. He was dealing directly with my FE developer on a separate issue and experiencing the same async and language barriers I was.
I walked through my handoff process:

items: Screen recordings and grabs with arrows

blocks.text: The Git automation was the highlight. He immediately understood its effectiveness and value to FE teams — less errors, less chasing, less imprecision.
He asked to implement the approach in other projects.

contentBlocks.sectionTitle: October 2024: UI Kit v1.0 + Component Library Maturity

blocks.text: By October, the component library had matured significantly:

items: Buttons (primary, secondary, tertiary) with full state variants
Sidebar navigation menu with item states
Input fields with validation, feedback, states
Card titles and page titles with consistent hierarchy
"Ready to Dev" / "Completed" tag system in Figma

Token Evolution:
Starting point:
150 CSS variables (mostly colour and type)

blocks.text: With no real-time communication possible, I developed systems to bridge the gap:

items: Element behaviour descriptions ("on hover X, on click Y")
Bright colour-coded sections for easy scanning
Once marked "Completed" by dev, colour removed but log preserved
Built isolated prototypes for specific features
Delivered screen recordings showing flows across multiple screens
Ensured flows made sense without verbal explanation
Visual separators between design and dev content
Separate playground file for testing (kept main file lightweight)
"Changes and Mods" sections visible at a glance
Used component configuration space for documentation
Specifications for both developers and future designers
Visual "Deprecated" markers in bright, unmissable colours
Clear communication about what replaces deprecated elements
Non-destructive structure to test new approaches: "To-Be-DEP" (deprecated) folder, "To-Change" testing folder, "MOD" prefix on modified values (prevents Git overwrites)

blocks.text: With CEO validation, Design Ops was officially established. I joined as Design Systems Lead while continuing UI/UX/Product work on my project.

items: 6 designers total (5 joined since I started)
Multiple tech stacks (React, Flutter, Vue, Nuxt, JS, JavaFX)
Only my project had a token pipeline
1 multi-format project (web, webapp, email, print, billing)
Limited time availability (still primary designer on my own project)

blocks.text: Option A: Build 1 Design System per project (duplicated work, inconsistency risk)
Option B: Headless Design System (complex governance, high initial overhead)
Option C (Chosen): Hybrid — Global Design System with project-specific flexibility

The Hybrid Model:
Global Library (Maintained by DS Lead):
Basic, well-built components with atomic nesting, states, boolean variants. Only modified by DS Lead.

Project Library Template:
Designers duplicate from base template. Already includes variable structure for brand, neutrals, system colours, spacing, typography, icons, borders.

Modification Rules:
Core tokens: NO modifications unless discussed. Semantic tokens: Can be modified with discussion. Extra types: Can be added as needed.

blocks.text: Rather than mandate adoption, I chose collaborative enablement:

items: What is a Design System — terminology, components, shared understanding
Components and Terminology — atomic design, nesting, variants
Design Principles — playground exercises, draft company principles
Design Tokens: Introduction — what they are, why they matter
Design Tokens: Naming & Structure — hierarchies, semantics, consistency
Token Studio + Git Flow — hands-on setup, transformation pipelines
Each designer audited their own project's brand assets (using template)
Each designer audited their own project's components (using template)
Used audits as starting point for global core tokens
Each designer created first draft of their project's core tokens
Separate library to avoid disrupting current workflows
Used as resources by me to draft global core tokens later

contentBlocks.title: Current State (June 2025)
contentBlocks.insight:
Adoption Status:
  • 5 of 7 projects have at least partial sturdy core tokens implemented
  • Education phase: Mostly complete
  • Implementation phase: Underway
  • Governance model: Established and documented
  • Global library: In active use
contentBlocks.result: The design system went from a rejected pitch to company-wide adoption in 18 months.
